transcript:
Feeding time for a baby can become a point of concern for many parents, as they want to make sure that their baby is getting all the right nutrients from the milk its drinking so that they can grow. The aspects of growth are weight, size, and brain development. The more advanced a baby is, the stronger it is. In 1983, proteins in babies were studied and the research showed that many babies were iron-deficient. This means that babies with an iron-deficiency may be less physically active and may develop more slowly, which may affect the child later on in life.

 But, how could it be possible for a baby to be iron-deficient so early on in its life? When a baby is inside its mother’s womb, it receives all the iron it needs because the mother’s womb is stockpiled with iron. However, the transfer of iron to the fetus becomes difficult in mothers that have high blood pressure or diabetes, or who smoke. To see if babies had issues with cognitive skills from being iron deficient, an EGG (electroencephalogram) experiment was performed in order to measure the electrical activity that comes from the brain. A baby needs to be able to recognize its own mother’s voice.

With the baby wearing an EEG net, a recording of the mother’s voice played, repeating the word, “baby” over and over again. Then, a “stranger’s” voice played, repeating the word “baby” over and over again. Researchers then analyzed the EEG patterns and the results were astounding. In an iron sufficient baby, they were able to memorize and differentiate between the two voices, which meant that the baby had a great memory. The iron-deficient baby, on the other hand, wasn’t able to distinguish the difference between the two voices, which meant that the baby’s hippocampus, the part of the brain involved with learning, was not functioning adequately. However, micronutrient deficiencies are quite common. 

Therefore, expectant mothers need to make sure they are as healthy as they can be during pregnancy and make sure they are eating the right types of food so that the baby can also receive those nutrients. If these issues could be resolved, it is estimated that the world’s IQ could shift positively by 10 points.

questions.text: How can an expectant mother make sure that her baby is receiving the right amount of nutrients while it is still in the womb?
answers: An expectant mother can take additional supplements.
An expectant mother needs to make sure she is eating the right types of food.
An expectant mother needs to make sure she is as healthy as she can be during pregnancy.

transcript:
For years we have heard that a baby is literally changing every day, little by little. But is growth actually continual like we think it is? In one study, the lengths and head measurements of 30 babies were recorded for a period of time. The parents were also asked to keep a journal to record their baby’s behaviour on a daily basis. At the start of the experiment, the babies were measured once a week and it was noted that baby growth happened in the span of one week. Next, the measurements were taken biweekly. Again, it was noted that a baby was growing even within half a week. Finally, the babies were measured daily. The growth that took place among the babies was surprising because it differed between 0.5 centimeters and 1.65 centimeters in the span of one 24-hour day. In between these days of extreme growth were days of no growth. This meant that the babies experienced growth in spurts.
 Additionally, it was noted that the growth spurts correlated to the baby’s behaviour, which showed up in the forms of temper tantrums, irregular sleep, and unsatisfied hunger. This data proved that growth doesn’t happen the way we think it does. Instead, growth happens in two very distinct phases. Unfortunately, this new data was criticized and disputed by the scientific community, even though it had been formally published and accepted warmly by the public. But occurrences such as these are not uncommon in the scientific world. Whenever new information is brought to light that challenges an older way of thinking, one can always be prepared for some push back. But the negative feedback isn’t always bad because this is how science evolves.

questions.text: In addition to the growth spurts, what else did the study discover?
answers: It was noted that the growth spurts correlated to the baby’s behaviour, which showed up in the forms of temper tantrums, irregular sleep, and unsatisfied hunger.
The study discovered that the growth spurts only happened at certain times during the day.
The study discovered that the growth spurts only happened when the baby was sleeping.

transcript:
As a baby begins to crawl, they begin to make decisions. How do babies use perception to guide their crawling movements? In an experiment, an adjustable slope apparatus was made and used to study which actions were possible for a baby and which ones weren’t. A successful trial meant that the baby could crawl from one end of the slope to other without falling or having an adult interfere to help. The babies who had just learned to crawl, the novice crawlers, were able to crawl across a flat slope, but showed poor judgement when it came to bigger slopes. The inability to properly judge what can actually be done is often seen in novice crawlers, as they just want to try everything and learn from their experience. 
The intermediate crawlers, babies who had a little more experience with crawling, were better judges of what they could and could not do. The advanced crawlers, as one may guess, were the best judges of all. The advanced crawlers seemed to know what they could and could not do, and they could also adjust their bodies accordingly to help them overcome any obstacle they encountered. As babies learn how to crawl, they become aware of the many ways they can move their bodies in any given environment and circumstance. 
Learning to crawl is essentially learning to behave in a flexible way. There are days when a baby can crawl and there are days when a baby can’t seem to crawl, but movement is not linear. Babies acquire the skills they need for movement in no particular order. This means that crawling is not a mandatory phase like everyone seems to think it is. Instead, crawling is just another way for a baby to move from one place to another.

questions.text: According to the study, the novice crawlers
answers: Showed average judgement as to what their body could and could not do.
Showed poor judgement when it came to the bigger slopes, but were willing to try and learn from their experience.
Knew what their bodies could and could not do, and they could adjust their bodies accordingly.
Cried when they saw a big slope

Crawling is not a mandatory phase.

transcript:
At the end of a baby’s first year of life, a baby starts to form words. In fact, babies start learning about languages even before they start crawling or walking. But if language is a complex thing, how do babies learn it? First it begins with a rhythm. For babies, language is all about flow. It is like music to them. They don’t understand the words that their parents are saying to them, but they are listening all the time and have been doing so since their days in their mother’s womb. In fact, research has shown that a baby can hear muffled sounds from the outside world inside their mother’s womb, and research has also shown that a baby can respond to voices and noises while inside its mother’s womb, and by the third trimester, a baby can already recognize the sound of its mother’s voice.
When babies listen to language, they essentially hear the rhythm of their native language and they are able to notice certain patterns in speech and can hear the difference in tone and pitch and can respond accordingly. This development begins as early as two days into a newborn’s life. Even at two days of age, babies can recognize the classes of language; for example, they can already understand that English and some other Germanic languages sound alike. In terms of language learning, babies are much more advanced than adults think they are. If parents take the time to have “conversations” with their babies, to carefully watch and listen to their baby while interacting with them, then parents will be in for a big surprise when they realize what their baby is learning and how their babies are communicating with them.

answers: Babies are able to notice certain patterns in speech and can hear the difference in tone and pitch.
Babies are able to notice which language the person is speaking.
Babies are able to understand the words being spoken to them.
Babies are able to notice the grammatical structure of the language

transcript: Forest farming, or agroforestry, is a combination of forests and farmland used in agriculture, and it has been practiced for thousands of years. There are numerous positive aspects of this particular farming practice. The most important is the preservation of forests, which plays a key role in fighting climate change. Also, trees prevent soil erosion, enrich the land, and help to conserve different living species. People who are in favor of agroforestry either plant acres of trees on patches of land, or start farming in forests that already exist. For instance, a man named Jono Neiger has created a farm alongside the Connecticut River in Massachusetts called Big River Chestnuts. He planted chestnuts, smaller trees, bushes, elderberries, and he released chickens into the forest. Agroforestry favors biodiversity and is associated with a variety of valuable species that thrive in cooler environments covered in shades, such as the shiitake mushrooms, as well as different medicinal plants. Forest farming protects forests and encourages planting more in order for agricultural engineers to make profits while preserving the environment.

transcript: Andrew Yang has been a champion for the notion that society must change capitalism so that it focuses more on what humans really want and need and less on creating wealth. He proposes an economic system, like the one in Singapore, that relies on the government to set investment policy, rather than an “invisible hand” offered in Adam Smith’s The Wealth of Nations. Traditionally, a country’s economy is measured using Gross Domestic Product (GDP) and economic progress. However, people then focus their time and energy to improve in those areas, rather than focusing on “normal life” activities. Under a new system, like the one Yang proposes, economic policy would be structured to maximize and also prioritize human well-being and fulfillment first—human capitalism. For Yang, human-centered capitalism would follow three core tenets: humanity is more important than money, the economy measures each person (particularly their well-being) and not each dollar, and markets serve human goals and values (not the other way around). As Yang eloquently put it, “Instead of having our humanity subverted to serve the marketplace, capitalism has to be made to serve human ends and goals.”

transcript:
Presently, there is a movement towards earning micro-credentials in addition to, or in lieu of, traditional university degrees. Micro-credentials have been described as bite-sized chunks of education, which include online courses, bootcamp certificates and apprenticeships with specialty providers and online learning platforms. According to Simon Nelson, CEO of FutureLearn, a learning platform that offers online courses through its partnerships with universities, micro-credentials have stemmed from three global “macro trends.” The first trend is that there is a higher demand for high-quality tertiary education. Secondly, the digital transformation experienced by many industries has created a skills gap left unfilled by traditional education systems. 

Finally, the higher education sector has been digitized in response to a greater demand for people to easily acquire new skills in addition to their university degree. Ultimately, micro-credentials are often sought after by companies looking to source talent beyond just university graduates and target candidates with non-traditional backgrounds. However, whether these new forms of education will replace or simply supplement university degrees remains unknown, since the current job market still values candidates who have earned degrees.

transcript: Education Farm is a new program located in Birmingham, Alabama designed to prepare young people for a future job market that will see an increased demand for digital skills. The program seeks to encourage children and adults to explore technology, pursue careers in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM), and learn to code through Swift, Apple’s coding language. Ed Farm is supported by Apple, which provided the program with all of the necessary hardware, software, funding, and professional learning support to ensure the program’s success. Apple granted Birmingham City Schools with over 400 devices that educators will use to deliver the program. Ed Farm also offers a Teacher Fellows program that trains educators from 13 Birmingham City Schools. In addition to professional development, educators are also provided with curriculums, new technology and instructional support. Outside of the city school system, the program also offers its Pathways program designed to reach adult learners who are interested in developing digital skills, acquiring post-secondary credentials and filling or creating new jobs in technology. The rise of coronavirus has brought with it an opportunity to test different futuristic technology designed to help prevent pandemics. Most of the tech is being used in China, however its use is likely to spread globally as more and more countries may need to rely on them to prevent an outbreak of their own. One technology currently being utilized is infrared thermometers, or thermometer guns, which health officials use to regularly check people’s temperatures. Robots have been programmed to complete tasks like disinfecting hospital rooms, communicating with people in quarantine, delivering medications and taking vitals. Self-driving vehicles are also being used to transport medical supplies short distances to hospitals. Even drones have been deployed to scan public places for people violating quarantine rules, spray disinfectant and conduct thermal imaging.

 AI has been called upon to track, diagnose and possibly treat the virus. There has also been an increase in facial recognition technology, and at least one company, Panasonic, claims its FacePro system can even identify people wearing masks. Combined with thermal imaging, these systems can also detect whether people have elevated temperatures. While these new technologies seem beneficial towards helping reduce the risk of a pandemic, it’s also quite chilling to realize that fear of a potential outbreak is being used to support heightened public surveillance.

transcript: Since 2014, the United States government has seized a total of 185,230 Bitcoins through criminal investigations. Once the US acquires any Bitcoin, the US Marshals then auctions them off to the public. Cryptocurrency enthusiast, Jameson Lopp, recently created a portal that approximated the total value of US government-seized Bitcoin at $151 million USD. Another enthusiast, Hard Fork, used the portal to estimate that each Bitcoin was sold for about $818 on average. However, had the US Marshals waited to sell the Bitcoins in their entirety, Lopp’s portal suggests they would have netted over $1.5 billion USD, assuming they were sold for $10,000 or more. In the UK, the Crown auctioned off its seized Bitcoin for the first time ever for $396,000 USD, or $8,365 each, which was well above the $8,000 market rate at the time. One country that has sold its Bitcoin for even higher profits is Bulgaria. The Bulgarian government recently sold about 200,000 Bitcoins to Asian investors and sovereign wealth funds for about $16,000 USD each. It’s apparent that governments are even susceptible to the volatile nature of trading cryptocurrency, which is apparent given that some have made large profits selling off their coins, while others not so much.

To date, the company owns about 500 Whole Foods grocery stores. Amazon has also added 26 Amazon Go convenience stores. The Amazon Go convenience stores are cashier-less stores that utilize different technologies such as computer vision, deep learning algorithms and sensor fusion that automate much of the purchase, checkout and payment processes. transcript:
Clinical gene-editing is just a fancy way of describing the process of changing DNA in human patients. When it comes to clinical gene-editing, there is changing the DNA of embryos and changing the DNA of individuals. Changes made to the genes found in individuals only affect the individual patient. 

However, changes made to the genes found in embryos are quite different because any changes would be heritable by future generations. For Jennifer Doudna, a scientist who is currently researching CRISPR gene-editing, this distinction is extremely important and there ought to be strict global regulation of embryonic gene-editing. However, she has been a proponent of individual gene-editing, given its potential to correct disease-causing mutations in patients. For example, recent clinical trials have been done to treat sickle cell anemia. On the other hand, there has been at least one documented case of the much more controversial embryonic gene-editing. In 2018, Chinese scientist, He Jianjui, altered the DNA of twin embryos, which resulted in twin girls being born with altered genomes. This immediately raised ethical concerns among, not only scientists in the field, but the entire global community as well. It’s impossible to remove embryonic gene-editing technology from existence, and so the scientific community, and humanity in general, must ensure the technology is better regulated.

questions.text: What is the difference between embryonic and individual gene-editing?
answers: Embryonic gene-editing is less controversial than individual gene-editing.
Individual gene-editing is less controversial than embryonic gene-editing.

Individual gene-editing makes heritable changes to the DNA.

answers: There is just one type of clinical gene-editing.

answers: Clinical gene-editing has both risks and benefits associated with it.

transcript:
In his recent TED Talk, sleep scientist Dan Gartenberg brought attention to the fact that as technology has improved so has the capability for people to work longer more productive work shifts. Gartenberg argues that this push for more productivity has come at the expense of less efficient sleep cycles, as more and more people have disrupted their naturally occurring circadian rhythms. In fact, Americans on average are sleeping one hour less per night than they were in the 1940’s.  While studies show the importance of sleep quantity, there are new studies showing that sleep quality is of great importance, too. 

According to Gartenberg, poor sleep and sleep apnea correlate with diseases like Alzheimer’s, cardiovascular disease, stroke and diabetes. It also leads to riskier behavior and lessens the capacity for empathy of others. He mentions that deep sleep, which is tracked using Delta brain waves, has been shown to be the most regenerative kind of sleep. Without deep sleep, studies show a severe decrease in learning capacity, long-term memory formation, personality development and cell recovery. It’s also the case that as humans age, there is a decrease in deep sleep Delta brain waves. As Gartenberg suggests, these waves are essentially a marker of a person’s biological youth. A lab in Germany recently discovered that certain sounds can increase Delta brain waves, causing deeper, more efficient sleep cycles. Gartenberg and other researchers are now developing deep sleep stimulating devices that could be worn during sleep.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a benefit of deep sleep?
Which of the following diseases does not correlate with poor sleep and sleep apnea, according to the text?
Who was likely the intended audience for Gartenberg’s TED Talk?
What is the main purpose of this text?
answers: To provide insight into the importance of deep sleep.
To explain how deep sleep functions.
To suggest people should sleep more infrequently.
To describe the study of deep sleep Delta brain waves.

transcript:
The Alliance of Small Island States - AOSIS - has a lot to say about climate change. And who could blame them? These are the islands and communities that will feel the most devastating impact climate change can bring. This isn't just about mild inconvenience. Entire islands are facing a future where they will be submerged by rising sea levels. It doesn't get more serious than that.

So who are the members of AOSIS? These are a coalition of 44 small islands and low lying coastal developing states, including five who have 'observer' status. You will find them throughout the African, Indian, and South China seas, in the Caribbean, and in the Pacific Ocean. Have you been on holiday recently to places like the Seychelles, Barbados, or Mauritius? Then you have visited one of the AOSIS! 

Remember how beautiful these places looked? If we don't do something about our climate crisis, these beautiful views might be no more. Still not convinced we have a problem? Well, look at it this way. More than half the territory of the Maldives is less than a metre above sea level. If global temperatures rise by around 1.5 °C, the IPCC (Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change) predicts that sea levels could rise by 26 to 77 centimetres by 2100.

It isn't just sea level rise that is a threat to AOSIS. The impact of flooding caused by increasingly powerful storms is also going to devastate these communities and the industries they are a part of, like farming and fishing. In short, anything we complain about in nations where we are inconvenienced by extreme weather could see the literal end of these small islands and low level coastal states.

So what is AOSIS trying to do to make a difference and protect their futures? AOSIS has implemented changes so their energy efficiency and sustainable development is as good as possible. Many have climate resilience projects in place to tackle the impact of climate change on their doorsteps. AOSIS also aims to help raise marginalised voices who fear for their lives and livelihoods if nothing is done to protect our planet. 

The core focus of the AOSIS campaign is to raise awareness about climate change, sustainable development, and ocean conservation. These islands and communities are leading the way with action on climate change and these other concerns, while other, richer nations stall to do anything to change their ways. What is it going to take for the world to understand the real threat of this global crisis, and do what needs to be done?

questions.text: What is AOSIS?
answers: The Alliance of Special Island Status
The Alliance of Small Island States
The Association of Small Island Status

questions.text: What worries the AOSIS most about climate change?
answers: It could ruin their tourist industry
Whole islands could be submerged below sea level
Climate change might cost a lot of money
That people might have to move home

questions.text: Which of the above nations mentioned has 50 percent of its territory under one meter above sea level?
The focus of AOSIS is to raise awareness about
answers: climate resilience, climate crisis, and climate change
climate change, ocean conservation, and sustainable development
sustainable development, financial impact, and climate change
ocean conversation, climate resilience, sustainable development

transcript:
Social media, for all its faults, is an amazing tool for language learners. Whether you prefer Instagram, Twitter, or the strange world that is Tumblr, social media can be an amazing language tool. Here are some reasons why.

Multiple language availability
All social media can be accessed in a range of languages, meaning you can change your settings to Italian, Spanish, Mandarin, and so many other languages. This is only one small change, and the language you need to understand how to use your preferred social media perhaps limited to words such as like, reblog, retweet, favourite, and so on. But this is still an important stepping stone to getting used to using your target language all the time.

Lessons whenever you want them
If you don't have much time to spare for studying, scrolling through the trending tags on Twitter from a country that speaks your target language can be a quick, bite-sized lesson. Or, you might follow an artist or actor whose native language is the one you are learning; keeping up to date with their Instagram posts and stories is a great way to get a little language practice in. There are lots of options for you!

Instant practice from all over the world
The internet has made international friendship easy, making awareness of different timezones one of the most important elements of keeping in touch. So once you are comfortable with Tweeting in your chosen language, or commenting on an Instagram post, maybe you can speak with your new friends in direct messages using the language you are learning.

Perfect grammar and vocabulary
The more you are exposed to the correct way to structure sentences, the easier grammar will be for you to understand. Equally, by having new vocabulary on the posts you are reading, every minute you 'waste' on social media is actually a learning experience. You have the perfect excuse!

Keep up to date with language
Sometimes when we learn a language traditionally, the language in our textbooks and other material can feel old, and outdated. By accessing Twitter, Instagram, and so on daily, not only can you be sure your language is the most modern used, but you will also pick up some current slang and expressions as well. Possibly even some curse words. Who doesn't like to curse?

So the next time someone says that you are wasting your time online scrolling through the same few websites, tell them to leave you alone. You are studying a whole new language! What better use of your time is there than that?

questions.text: Which of these is not social media?

transcript:
The Aral Sea was once the world’s fourth largest inland lake and home to a large variety of fish. Now a tenth of its original size, the Aral Sea is regarded as one of the world’s largest man-made environmental disasters. 
In the 1960s, the Aral Sea started to retreat. At that time no one thought about the Aral Sea’s fate. No one thought that it would dry up and lead to an ecological catastrophe. The water from the two rivers that fed the Aral Sea was used for irrigation without any consideration of the consequences. The fashion industry plays a part in this story, as cotton was one of the main crops that was grown with the water. Cotton requires vast amounts of water. For example, it takes 2,700 liters of water to grow enough cotton for a single T-shirt. 
The Aral Sea shrank so much that it became divided into two parts, now known as the Large and Small Aral Seas. This had a devastating effect on the lives of local people and animals.  In an effort to save the Small Aral Sea, a dam was built between the Large and Small Aral Seas in 2005. The water levels in the Small Aral Sea rose significantly, enough for fish to return and small-scale fishermen to resume fishing. 
But the sea has not returned everywhere. The Large Aral Sea remains a shadow of its former size, although there are still some who remain optimistic that one day the sea will return to its former glory.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the Aral Sea is true?
answers: It started to retreat in the 1960s.
It is the world’s fourth largest lake.
It is ten times bigger than it used to be.

questions.text: What does the text say about the fashion industry?
answers: The cotton industry shrank the Aral Sea.
The Aral Sea is a fashion hotspot.
It takes 2,700 liters of water to grow a cotton plant.
The Aral Sea produces cotton T-shirts.

questions.text: What happened in 2005?
answers: A dam was built between the Large and Small Aral Seas.
The Aral Sea was divided into two parts.
The water levels rose througout the Aral Sea.

transcript:
Data leaks and privacy scares are becoming more common as we continue to share more and more of our lives over the Internet. There has also been a lot of speculation about who controls our Facebook news feeds. The answer is that you have a surprising amount of control over your feed. Well, you, and a small team of engineers in Menlo Park, California. 
When you open Facebook, a powerful algorithm scans everything posted by each of your friends, each group you belong to and everyone you follow. Then, the algorithm ranks everything according to what it believes you will find the most interesting and displays it for you on your news feed. 
The results of this ranking process are consumed by Facebook’s 1 billion plus active users, a full one-fifth of the world’s adult population. Most users will only ever see the top few hundred posts, making this closely-guarded algorithm one of the most influential and controversial in the world. The algorithm’s viral power shapes our social lives and reading habits.
In a way, each time we like a post on Facebook we are “voting” on how accurate the algorithm is. The like button is more than just a way for users to interact on the site. It is a way for Facebook to figure out how best to filter its users' news feeds. The fact that we can personalize our own Facebook experience is very important. In fact, it allowed Facebook to develop its latest algorithm, which works by ranking posts according to how likely users will be to react positively to them.

questions.text: What makes Facebook’s algorithm so influential?
answers: Most users will only see the top few hundred posts.
The algorithm knows all your personal data.

questions.text: What does the text say about the like button?
answers: Facebook uses it to figure out how to filter our news feeds.
It is a way to vote on how much we like Facebook.
It shapes our social lives and reading habits.
You cannot use it to personalize your Facebook experience.

transcript:
Paul Salopek is a journalist who is walking across the world to discover the story of humanity. 
He is tracing the 21,000-mile migration of our ancestors. He began walking in Ethiopia, the birthplace of our first human ancestors. He plans to walk across Asia and then down along the western coast of North America until he reaches the very tip of South America. It is a journey that will take him at least ten years to complete. 
Paul practices slow journalism. He believes that it’s important to slow down, study the world around him closely and interact with people at a human level and pace. 
Paul says that the first thing you learn about walking is that slowing down allows you to think. You are forced to focus on the visible, physical world at your feet. Walking makes use of our problem-solving brains. Each day you must figure out how to cross rivers or deserts, how to find roads, leave roads, find water or find people.
Every 100 miles Paul takes a “milestone reading.” This involves taking a panoramic photo, plus a picture of the sky and his boots on the ground. He also records a video with the first person he sees. He encourages other would-be journalists to take similar “milestone readings,” which involve recording their immediate environment and writing down their impressions of each milestone in their journal.

questions.text: What is a “milestone reading”?
answers: A record of your immediate environment at a specific point.
An interview with the first person you see.
The practice of writing things down in your journal.

questions.text: When does Paul take a milestone reading?
answers: When he meets a new person.
At the end of each day.

transcript:
We are facing an epidemic of loneliness and social isolation. In a recent study, nearly half of Americans reported feeling lonely.
Why are so many of us so lonely? Many experts believe that social media may be one of the main culprits. Lonely people are more likely to go online when they feel isolated, and the Internet can temporarily give them a feeling of social satisfaction, even though it eventually isolates people. Also, our community and civic society have been slowly breaking down. 
John Cacioppo, who was a psychologist at the University of Chicago, wrote a book about loneliness and how to deal with it. He used the acronym EASE to help people ease their way back into feeling connected. The first E stands for “extend yourself.” He recommended volunteering or doing community service in an area that you enjoy.
The A stands for “action plan.” Go through your phone and other social media contacts and start reaching out to other people. Ask others about themselves and their interests.
The S is “seek collectives.” As humans, we find it easier to bond with people who have similar values, activities and interests.  
Last but not least, “Expect” the best. Give others the benefit of the doubt. Lonely people tend to feel more easily socially threatened, but it’s important to approach others with optimism. Once you’ve done so, you’ve made the first step in escaping from the trap of loneliness.

questions.text: What does social media have to do with loneliness?
answers: It gives a permanent feeling of social satisfaction.
People usually don’t go online when they feel isolated.

questions.text: What is an example of “extending yourself”?
answers: Asking other people about their interests.
Meeting people who have similar values.

questions.text: What is the main point of the text?
answers: To scare people away from using social media.
To let people know they can break free from loneliness.
To give a scientific report on the rise of loneliness.
To promote John Cacioppo’s book on loneliness.

transcript:
The dominance of the English language can’t be challenged. English is an official language in 54 countries and 27 territories, making it the most spoken language in the world. English does not have the highest number of native speakers, that title goes to Mandarin and Spanish. However, English is the most popular second language worldwide, and with an estimated 1.8 billion people using English, it easily tops the list of official languages spoken around the world. 
But is English really capable of taking over the world? At first glance, the growth of English seems convenient. It makes it easy for us to communicate when travelling abroad or doing business overseas. However, some people believe that the spread of English represents a worrying problem. They believe that the world is threatened by English and that it’s bringing about the premature death of other languages. Experts say that one language disappears every two weeks, and that we are in danger of losing over half of the world’s 6,500 languages in the next century. When the last speaker of a language dies, all of the information contained within that language also dies.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about English?
answers: It is the most spoken language in the world.
It has the highest number of native speakers.
It is the second most popular language worldwide.
It is an official language in 81 countries.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true according to the text?
answers: English makes it easy for us to do business overseas.
Spanish or Mandarin will soon replace English.
Soon, more than 1.8 billion people will speak English.
Some people are challenging the dominance of English.

questions.text: What do some people believe about the spread of English?
answers: It’s causing the premature death of other languages.
It caused the death of 6,500 other languages.

transcript:
Over the last few decades numerous diets and food trends have come and gone. With contradictory advice coming from nutritionists and doctors, it can be difficult to find a feasible diet. Lately, intermittent fasting has seen a rise in popularity. Fasting is ancient and steeped in tradition, with most religions advocating some form of fasting. Scientists now believe that our body is designed to deal with a scarcity of food. They say that we are genetically programmed for metabolic rest for 12-18 hours overnight because our DNA has not yet evolved to handle the regular stream of food that we feed ourselves throughout the day. 
There are many forms of intermittent fasting. One method is to fast for 16 hours a day and eat during the remaining 8 hours. Another form involves fasting for two days a week (consuming between 500 - 600 calories) and eating normally for the other five days. 
Research done on animals has shown that intermittent fasting reduces the risk of obesity, diabetes and cancer. A recent student found that mice who fasted lived longer and were healthier than their counterparts who had constant access to food. 
The purpose of intermittent fasting is to trigger autophagy, or “self eating,” in which the body literally eats itself. This is an important detoxification function in the body that cleans out damaged cells and creates new ones. 
It’s safe to say that, as humans, we’re prone to overconsumption. Fasting - whether we give up food, shopping or social media consumption -  may prove to have benefits that we can’t ignore.

questions.text: What is autophagy?
answers: A process in which the body starts to eat itself.
A dangerous function that damages cells.
A recent study about fasting and obesity.

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of intermittent fasting?
answers: Not eating for 2 days a week and eating normally for the other 5.
Not eating for 8 hours a day and eating normally for the other 16.

transcript:
Bad language, violence, drug and alcohol abuse - critics have no trouble finding reasons to dislike video games. Grand Theft Auto is particularly controversial, which each new release seemingly more extreme than its predecessor. 
For the British computer game designer Richard Bartle, the appeal of online RPGs (role-playing games) is that they are free from the pressures of daily life. “In video games, we are free to be who we really are - or at least find out who we really are if we don’t already know.” He said that video games offered people a chance to simply be themselves. 
In a study published in 2012, a team of psychologists found that video games allowed players to be their “ideal selves,” for example, to experience themselves as braver or more generous. They noted that a player’s disposition is often reflected in their choice of character. In RPGs, players who assume the role of the medic (whose job is to keep the rest of the team alive in battle), will tend to play the same role in other games as well. 
Bartle believed that these kinds of games are a search for identity. “Basically,” he said, “if you’re a jerk in real life, you’re going to be a jerk in any kind of social setting, and if you’re not, you’re not.” 
Returning to Grand Theft Auto, we find that it offers its players a playground. Video game worlds provide people with places where they can act free of judgment or punishment. Interestingly, freed of meaningful consequences, people continue to act according to their personality. As the philosophers say: wherever you go, there you will be.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a criticism of video games?
What did Richard Bartle say about RPGs?
answers: People can be themselves when they play.
People can try out new identities.
People are free to act without consequences.
People experience too much pressure when they play.

questions.text: What did psychologists find in their 2012 study?
answers: A player’s choice of character reflects his disposition.
People behave worse in video games than in real life.
People believe they are more generous than they really are.
Video games are not a good place to be yourself.

questions.text: What does the text say about Grand Theft Auto?
answers: It is a place for people to act free of judgment.
It has a bad influence on young players.

transcript:
Growth is good, right? Since World War II, GDP (gross domestic product) has been used to determine economic growth and a country’s overall prosperity. But now, some researchers and activists are questioning if growth is actually good. 
In 1972, a report called The Limits to Growth was published by a team at MIT. The report simply stated that on a planet of limited resources, infinite growth isn’t possible. Eventually, non-renewable resources like oil and gas will run out.
This conclusion has led to the degrowth movement, which claims that the economy is largely responsible for an increase in carbon emissions and the climate crisis. Supporters of the degrowth movement call for a drastic reduction in energy and material use, which would mean the death of GDP. The degrowth movement believes that we need to separate the idea of progress and economic growth. The definition of economic success would change, resulting in a shorter work week and more free time. This shift in our cultural values could be  a way to change how we measure success and well-being, thereby addressing the growing financial and social inequalities that we currently face. 
Ultimately, degrowth would mean that we’d have less stuff. With fewer people working to produce goods and materials, there wouldn’t be as many brands in supermarkets or so much clothing in shops. We’d have to take trains and buses instead of planes, and our free time would be spent doing free activities with loved ones rather than shopping and spending money.

questions.text: The Limits to Growth stated that…
answers: we need to find more resources.
oil and gas are about to run out.

questions.text: What is degrowth?
answers: A limitation of energy and material use.
A way to determine a country’s prosperity.
The way in which we measure success.
The movement responsible for carbon emissions.

questions.text: How would degrowth affect our daily lives?
answers: We would have the same amount of stuff.
We would have to walk or cycle everywhere.
We would have to work for free.

transcript:
We hear a lot about how bad social media is for us, though we all still use it. So it can't be that bad, right? Like anything in life, there are good and bad points to Twitter, Instagram, Facebook, and whatever other social media you use. 

Anonymity
Anonymity is great, isn't it? We can be whoever we want to be when we are online, keeping our private lives completely separate. Anonymity also means we can keep ourselves as secure as possible, so would-be identity thieves can't access our personal details. Which is great. What is not so great about anonymity on social media as actually the same thing that is good about it; how can you really be sure who anybody is? People can be anyone; that doesn't necessarily mean they are being good!

Community
One great part of all social media is networking and making friends. If you follow the Twitter account of a favourite TV show or the Instagram of a singer you like, you will get to 'meet' all kinds of people who share your interest. This makes us feel closer to the rest of the world, break down communication barriers, and overall lets us meet people we like. Though it also means social media is faceless, and sometimes that makes people forget there are real people behind the accounts. We can be cruel and unkind to strangers, not think before we speak, and when there is an argument, take sides that turn disagreement into bullying. The social media community is not so great when that happens!

Safety and help
Social media has been a great help after natural disasters like earthquakes and tsunamis, helping people locate their loved ones and know where to go for shelter. For terrorist attacks, social media has helped keep people informed, safe, and help with coordinating emergency services. People even offer taxi services and spare rooms to help those in need. Equally, social media can be used to track down people who don't want to be found, like those who have left abusive relationships. Social media is filled with scams that rely on people being too trusting;  especially when there are events like natural disasters. Social media can do good, but can also do so much bad.

News 
If you want to keep up to date with the latest news, places like Twitter are the place to go. With published news and personal views on everything that is happening in our world literally posted every second, you will always know what is going on. Which is not ideal for some; sometimes bad news is impossible to look away from, making us nervous or anxious. Sometimes the news on social media isn't factual either. If we don't use critical thinking and just blindly trust what we read, social media can be a dangerous place.

Social media. Good and bad, right and wrong, fun and frustrating; we know these things, and yet still can't keep ourselves away!

questions.text: What is the best thing about the social media community?
answers: Being able to be unkind to people we don't know
Everything can be trusted on social media
How many arguments we can have online every day

transcript:
Sea turtles seem to think that sea debris smells like food. Sea debris could be anything like cigarette butts, fishing gear or plastic bags. Researchers at the University of North Carolina have discovered that ocean plastics inhabited by algae and microscopic ocean life, produce similar odors to the food eaten by sea turtles. Plastic in the form of plastic bags usually don't have a strong odor when we come into contact with it. Once this material ends up in the ocean, sea life tends to make it their homes. 
Algae and microscopic organisms release compounds such as dimethyl sulfide which give off a really foul-smelling odor. Due to these compounds, the material starts to smell like food that sea turtles eat. A study was conducted to find out why sea turtles were attracted to plastic. Kayla Goforth and her team at the University of Georgia Marina Extension, took empty bottles and submerged them in an experimental water tank.  They decided to put fifteen Loggerhead turtles into this tank for testing purposes. A pipe ran into the tank and a fan blew the odors across the surface of the water. Four tests were conducted with deionized water, clean plastic as controls, turtle food and aged sea plastic. The team tracked the time spent out of the water and how many breaths they took. These turtles usually remain underwater for about 4 to 5 minutes and exchange air as they return to the surface.  It has been suggested that the main reason sea turtles end up eating and getting tangled in plastic is because they smell it out just like food. Additionally, plastic appears to look like jellyfish as they float, which could confuse sea turtles. Everyone  should be careful when using plastic as it might end up in the ocean, which is detrimental to turtles.

questions.text: What compound does algae and microscopic organisms release?
What was the aim of this study?
answers: To find out why whales made strange sounds.
To find out why sharks ate plastic and metals.
To find out  why fish swam near plastic regularly.
To find out why sea turtles were attracted to plastic.

questions.text: What type of turtles did they use in the experiment?
How many minutes do turtles usually stay underwater for?

transcript:
Elon Musk has been asked by NASA to help explore a nearby asteroid. This asteroid contains so much gold that anyone can become a billionaire on earth. SpaceX, owned by Elon Musk, will join NASA to launch an uncrewed spacecraft to the solid metal blob called 16 Psyche. This could happen as early as 2022. The asteroid is very unique because it appears to be mostly made of exposed nickel-iron, which is from an early planet. 
Pysche contains a lot of platinum, iron and nickel. It is also 193 km wide. The estimated value of all these metals are worth $15.8 quadrillion. If all these metals were brought back to earth, the world's economy would collapse as there would be an oversupply of metals. The value on earth would decrease significantly. The SpaceX Falcon rocket has been sent to the International Space Station (ISS) with a load of supplies. 
This trip is to examine what the asteroid is made of and there is no intention of any mining. NASA scientists are confident to suggest that 16 Psyche is a survivor of planetary collisions. When the solar system was forming, collisions occurred regularly. Through this information, it could tell us how the earth's core and other planets were formed. The probe will hopefully reach the chunk of metal in 2026. Jupiter Trojan asteroids are considered to be relics of the solar system's earlier era. There is a possibility that Psyche is one of these relics. Every year four to five million ounces of gold is brought to the market which is not much compared to the amount in space. Asteroid ownership was made legal in 2015. Two space mining companies, Deep Space Industries and Planetary Resources are planning to get in on the action.

questions.text: What has Elon Musk been asked to do?
answers: To help investigate a new planet.
To help look for a brand new star.
To help explore a nearby asteroid.

transcript:
Social media is a great way to keep up to date with everything that is happening in the world, and to help us make new friends. It can be great for keeping in contact with people, and gives us the chance to see things from new perspectives. Though social media can also contribute to one of the worst parts of being online; cyber-bullying.

When we post online or comment on other posts, much of what we do can be anonymous. Though whether we choose to share our personal details on Twitter, Instagram, and so on or we use pen names, we can still be victim to bullying. Or be the bullies ourselves! When we feel like saying something unkind, or don't think before we speak, it is an entirely different experience saying those words face to face than over the internet. Face to face, most of us would pause and think, but online the impact of those words perhaps doesn't feel so strong to the bullies. Though to those being bullied, whether their real name or their pen name is used, the impact can be awful.

So what is cyber-bullying, really? It is the kind of bullying that uses digital technologies, including social media. Bullying can include spreading lies, sharing embarrassing photos, sending hurtful messages or messages encouraging someone to hurt themselves, and impersonating someone sending cruel messages in their name. This can happen to anyone online, child and adult alike. 

The impact of bullying ranges, depending on the individuals involved. For some, it can be a physical thing like losing sleep, stomach ache, and headaches. For others, bullying can result in feeling upset, angry, embarrassed, and all sorts of other negative emotions. And in some cases continued bullying means a person will lose all interest in the things they once loved, as well as trust in those around them.

Social media is beginning to take cases of bullying seriously. On Facebook and Instagram, we can send anonymous reports, and on Twitter users are encouraged to report bullying accounts. Cyber-bullying can be a very lonely, frightening experience, and it can feel like these platforms are doing little to help. They aren't doing enough, but as awareness of cyber-bullying increases, hopefully our understanding of what it means to be bullied will as well. 

Our online lives have become equally important to our offline ones, so when things like cyber-bullying happen, the answer isn't as easy as just walking away. The answer is that we work together, as members of the public choosing better ways to express our disagreements with strangers online, and social media platforms like Twitter doing all they can to make their spaces safe.

questions.text: Who is responsible for helping to stop cyberbullying?

transcript:
For the last century, the world’s most valuable resource was oil. However, now that we’re well rooted in the digital age, the value of data is soaring. It’s a little too simplistic however, to claim, “Data is the new oil!” Oil is a commodity, whereas data is an asset. But what’s the difference? Well, a commodity is an asset whereby each unit has the same value as another, such as oil, cocoa, coffee, gold or any other resource. But not all assets are commodities. Some examples of an asset are a house or a used car. The value of assets is not uniform i.e. two used cars are not necessarily worth the same amount of money. 

Data is an asset which grows in value as it is used. To that end, one person’s data is of very little value, but the data of thousands of people is worth a fortune in the modern age because of how it can be used to improve services. For example, a company like Amazon, which wants to connect with customers or suppliers on demand, utilizes user data to match the customer with ideal products. Even YouTube works in this way: your homepage is tailored exactly to your tastes because of the video content you’ve watched before. An e-commerce company like Amazon or Alibaba can also interpret the data of its users to gain insight on market trends, users’ shopping habits, popular products and popular sales times. 

Plenty of companies do sell data of course, to other companies that wish to improve their own services. But the important thing to note is that data is more than just a saleable asset; it’s at the core of an organisation’s performance. The data that companies like Amazon and Alibaba have is of course incredibly valuable to third parties, but it’s even more valuable to the company itself! Much like selling your car might be a mistake as it will leave you without a car, it’s counterintuitive for these companies to sell all their data, as it’s much more valuable in the company’s possession than in the possession of another.

questions.text: What is the main idea of the text?
answers: Assets and commodities are not the same.
Data is now more valuable than oil.
Data is of immense value to modern companies.
Data is best being sold for financial gain.

transcript:
The Durian fruit, which grows in Southeast Asia, is infamous for having an overwhelmingly pungent odour but a delicious, rich taste. Scientists in Sydney though have discovered a new use for it though, having created a way of using the Durian fruit to store energy for rapidly charging our electrical devices. It’s a little more complicated than simply plugging your iPhone into the flesh of the infamously foul-smelling fruit though! In a new scientific paper by University of Sydney professor Vincent G. Gomez though, the author describes a novel method for turning biowaste from these fruits into “supercapacitors” which can hold large amounts of energy. Since the materials used to make batteries are in rapid decline, there is now a bigger demand for alternative sources of energy storage. These electrochemical supercapacitors have the ability to store large amounts of energy, but can also be refilled when empty, unlike regular batteries, which are useless once the chemical within has been depleted. 

But what’s the difference between a supercapacitor and a rechargeable lithium ion battery like the one that’s in your iPhone? They work in a similar way, but supercapacitors like the Durian fuelled one don’t contain toxic metals and can be recharged indefinitely without “wearing out”. Supercapacitors consist of large metal plates which are coated in a porous substance such as activated charcoal, or indeed the even more porous flesh of the durian fruit. These porous, or absorbent, qualities work just like a sponge, allowing a greater charge to be absorbed and stored within the capacitor. The only problem is that it is still quite an expensive exercise, but if the researchers can find a way of bringing it into the mainstream with a relatively low cost, it could be a huge boost in our fight against environmental unsustainability. "Converting food wastes into value-added products will not only improve the overall economy, but also reduce environmental pollution," the researchers wrote in their paper.

questions.text: What is the main idea of the text?
answers: Scientists have discovered a new species of fruit that has a bad smell.
Scientists have found a way of using fruit waste to help store energy.
Scientists have discovered that we can charge our phone by plugging it into a durian fruit.
Scientists have discovered that the Durian fruit tastes much better than it smells.

transcript:
You may not have noticed this before, but languages from warmer climates like Hawaiian, Tagalog and often flow easily, with lots of spacious, open vowel sounds. On the other hand, languages like Russian, Danish and and Norwegian are filled with consonants and narrow vowel sounds. A new study of over 600 languages suggests that the development of our languages is affected in large part by its climate, and its terrain. This kind of linguistic development has long been acknowledged in the animal world; birds tend to sing at a higher pitch in urban environments to help them be heard more easily, whereas forest-dwelling birds sing at a lower frequency. 

However, this new body of research carried out by University of California linguists Ian Maddieson and Christophe Coupe is the first to suggest that human language has followed a similar developmental pattern. They gathered data on 633 world languages, omitting widely spoken international languages such as English, Mandarin and Spanish because they are no longer limited to one climate. Using these language samples, they cross-analyzed them with ecological and climatic data to find out if indeed our languages are affected by our surroundings. A very clear pattern revealed itself: Languages in hotter, more tropical areas were often more full-bodied and melodious, and used much fewer consonants. In contrast, languages in colder, drier and more mountainous areas were much harsher in sound, and contained a lot more consonants.

answers: Birds’ speech is affected by their environment.
Human languages are affected by their environment.

The English language is widely spoken.

The Russian language is made up of many flowing vowel sounds.
The Danish language contains a lot of consonant sounds.

questions.text: Which of the following is not mentioned in the text?
answers: The reason why climate affects language.
The reason why English was not included in the study.
All of the above are mentioned.

transcript:
Normally, when we dream during sleep, we’re not aware that what we’re experiencing is actually not real. It doesn’t matter how outlandish or bizarre the dream is, we believe it. It’s only when we wake up that we notice how unrealistic the dream was. However, about 40% of us experience “lucid dreaming” at least once in our lives. This is when we become aware, while dreaming, that our dream is actually a dream. 

Often, when we suddenly realize that we’re dreaming, the shock  forces us into wakefulness. But for those of us who can remain asleep, this realization can give us control over our dreams! Imagine being able to turn your nightmare into a great adventure, one where you can fly, be invisible, have super strength, or live out any other fantasy you’ve ever had. Well, skilled lucid dreamers can do just that. The idea of lucid dreaming became incredibly popular after it inspired the 2010 film Inception, but the earliest record of it was made by Ancient Greek philosopher Aristotle during the 4th century B.C. 

But can we train ourselves to lucid dream, or is simply an in-born talent that certain people have? For most, lucid dreaming is just a spontaneous occurrence, where they suddenly find themselves able to control aspects, or indeed the entire narrative or setting of their dream, but the last decade has seen a rise in the number of people who are ‘training’ themselves to lucid dream. Many experienced lucid dreamers and trainers claim that it has a multitude of benefits, from allowing people to overcome phobias by encountering them in the dream state, to boosting their own creativity. For others, it’s simply a way of seeking adventure and escape from their own lives, like a kind of virtual reality game.

questions.text: What is the main purpose of the text?
answers: To encourage us to watch the film Inception.
To inform us about lucid dreaming.
To warn us about lucid dreaming.
To promote the practice of lucid dreaming.

transcript: Mushrooms are abundant, grow almost anywhere, and they’re both strong and biodegradable. These characteristics make it increasingly likely that mushrooms will soon be used to help aid many of the world’s problems. While we associate mushrooms only with eating, the edible part is just its body that grows above the ground. Below the surface however, mushrooms span out in a huge interconnected network of filaments called mycelium, which is renowned for being a tough and lightweight material. Mycelium is now being used by a growing number of engineers and even designers to make items from hats to shoes, and lighting fixtures to furniture! The reason for this is that it is so environmentally sustainable. Mushrooms can be grown very easily, even using food waste, and can be grown into any shape. They’re cheap to grow too, needing only water, some food from our own household waste, and air. Almost any type of waste has a species of fungi that can break it down and feed on it; there’s even one species that can soak up toxic metals, one that can eat plastic, and some that can grow on nuclear waste! While it might be quite a while until we all accept the idea of “growing” clothes from mycelium, waste-digesting mushrooms are already being used to help clean up the environment. At the site of the world's biggest oil spill in the rainforests of Ecuador, scientists are planning to grow giant mushrooms which will soak up toxic oil from deep down in the soil!

answers: Mycelium forms a large, underground network of interconnected life forms.
Mushrooms can be used to “eat” toxic waste.
All of the above are true.

transcript:
USA based scientists have developed a new piece of technology that allows amputees to control a prosthetic arm by simply using their mind. It’s called “nerve interface technology”, and it works by using muscle grafts, machine algorithms and electrodes to magnify the amputees’ faint nerve signals. These amplified nerve signals are then sent to the prosthetic limb in real time, effectively mimicking the function of a real limb. The technology, which until now existed only in the fictional world, is still in its early testing stage, and has only been applied to prosthetic arms thus far. Study co-author Dr Robert Oneal, of the University of Michigan, has labelled this “the biggest advance in motor control for people with amputations in many years.” The study used only four test subjects and each used the already existing Mobius Bionics LUKE arm. 

Initially, the researchers and developers found that the nerve signals in the amputated limb were too weak to be received by the electrodes they had inserted in the prosthetic arm, but by placing miniscule muscle grafts around the nerves, they were able to increase the strength of these signals. During the trial, the four participants were able to continuously pick up objects, make hand signals and move their fingers and thumbs individually simply by using thought. According to the researchers, the nerve interface worked for a little under one year before needing any adjustments or recalibration. One participant claimed, “It’s just like having a hand again… It brings back a sense of normality.” As of now, the researchers are planning on taking the technology into clinical trials.

transcript:
UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson recently announced that research was being done to test the possibility of a bridge connecting Scotland and the island of Ireland. The idea of connecting the neighbouring islands of Ireland and Great Britain by road has long been a popular one, but it has always been dismissed as impossible. In this most recent reincarnation of the idea, the locations for each entry to the bridge are the Scottish coastal town of Portpatrick and Larne on the northeast coast of Northern Ireland. If completed, this bridge would reach 40 kilometers in length, making it the world’s longest bridge built over open sea. That title is currently held by the Hangzhou Bay Bridge in China, while spans 36 kilometers across the Qiantang River Delta. 
The bridge poses a number of significant challenges though, not only regarding its length. The Irish Sea reaches depths of up to three hundred meters, and the sea bed would have to be dug into to lay the foundations for the bridges support structure. As well as this, it would have to be built very high to allow ships to pass under safely, as the Irish Sea is an exceedingly busy body of water for commercial ships.

 Ian Firth of the International Association for Bridge and Structural Engineering suggests that there are alternative solutions though. “We could use floating foundations; the Norwegians have already done this for their own sea bridges.” In theory, this would entail a pontoon floating on the surface, which is tethered to the seabed to prevent it from floating very far. This would allow engineers to build the structure of the bridge on these floating platforms, rather than having to build hundreds of metres down through the sea. However, questions have been asked of the practicality of such a bridge. Northern Ireland and Scotland experience frequent inclement weather such as heavy rain, dense fog and gale force winds. Thus, cynics claim that while the bridge would cost an enormous sum of money, it would spend a great deal of its time closed to the public.

questions.text: Which of these are not mentioned as obstacles that the bridge will create?
answers: The bridge would be very expensive.
The public would have little interest in using the bridge.
Bad weather conditions would limit the use of the bridge.
The bridge could disrupt or endanger shipping traffic.

transcript:
The sports brand Nike seems to have been around forever, such is its ubiquity in modern culture. However, it’s only actually existed since 1972, and it could have been a very different brand to what it is now. Originally founded in 1964 as Blue Ribbon Sports by Bill Bowerman, a university track and field coach, and his former student Phil Knight, it underwent a rebrand with the launch of the first Nike shoe in 1972. Six years later, Blue Ribbon Sports was renamed Nike, Inc. and they went public in 1980. However, before the launch of the now iconic shoe in 1972, the Nike narrative almost went in a completely different direction. 

Phil Knight writes in his book, Shoe Dog, that he’d ordered 3,000 pairs of sports shoes from a factory in Mexico, and he needed to make them appealing to the market. He hired a designer by the name of Carolyn Davidson and asked her to come up with a logo which evoked the idea of ‘motion’. In return for just $35, she came up with the now famous “swoosh” logo. Knight confesses that he didn’t like the logo much, but since his business partners did, he decided to let it go. Now all they needed was a name. After much deliberation, they were left with a choice of two: Falcon and Dimension Six. In a poll of their employees, neither was particularly popular, but the general consensus was that everyone hated Dimension Six apart from Knight, who himself had thought of the name. 

The night before the final decision had to be made, Knight’s head salesman Jeff Johnson had a dream. In this dream, he thought of the name Nike, the Greek goddess of victory. Upon hearing the name, Knight noted that many big brands had short names with strong letters like K and X; Kleenex, Xerox, Clorox etc. He also conceded that a brand named after the goddess of victory was an idea he liked, but, he writes, he wasn’t yet convinced. With the deadline to publicize the brand name upon them, Knight reluctantly elected for the name Nike. “Maybe it’ll grow on me,” He thought.

answers: The location where the shoes were manufactured.
The reason Knight did not like the logo.
The names of both Nike founders.

questions.text: Which of the following is true?
answers: Carolyn Davidson came up with the name Nike.
Knight didn’t like anything about the name Nike.
Knight wanted to call the company Dimension Six.
Knight wanted to call the company Falcon.

transcript:
The genetic make-up of an octopus is so vastly different from any other form of life on earth, that some imaginative zoologists have gone as far as labelling it an alien life form! This of course suggests that the octopus is not even originally from this planet, which seems quite far fetched. Regardless of whether or not the octopus is actually an alien being, it has been found to be one of the most mystifying species in the animal kingdom, as no other invertebrates, i.e. animals with no backbone, display the intelligence of an octopus. In 2015, scientists managed to decode the genome of the octopus. Through studying all 2.7 billion characters of its genetic code, they found that its incredible intelligence developed much earlier than that of vertebrates. In fact, octopuses emerged on planet earth about 400 million years ago, 230 million years before mammals. 

“They were the first intelligent beings on the planet.”said Clifton Ragsdale of the University of Chicago, who helped lead the research project. It’s this intelligence, and indeed some almost “supernatural” powers that fascinate people like Ragsdale. For example, they’ve been shown to be able to figure out ways of escaping enclosures, even by using their “suckers” to grip and twist the lid of a closed jar in which it is trapped. They can fit through incredibly small spaces, despite their large size since they have no backbone, and can also hunt prey while it’s on land by jumping from the water at a high speed. They’ve even been documented using shells and other marine objects as tools! These traits all display incredible levels of intelligence, but making it almost supernatural is the octopus’ ability to simply detach one of its limbs if attacked and trapped! And finally, the octopus is a master of camouflage and shape shifting. It can mimic other animals and even the environment around, making it almost totally invisible...

It’s time to treat the octopus with some serious respect, it seems!

questions.text: According to the information in the text, which of these is not true?
answers: Octopuses have been on the planet for longer than humans.
Octopuses were the first intelligent life form on earth.
Octopuses can hide from danger very effectively.

transcript:
In a startling new discovery, research has shown that the speech of penguins follows some of the same rules and principles as human speech.There are two main laws of language that penguins have been found to adhere to. First, Zipf’s Law of Brevity, which dictates that the words we most frequently use, in almost any human language, are shorter and easy to say. Then there’s the Menzerath-Altmann Law, whereby longer words are composed of extra, but shorter, syllables. Language evolves slowly over many long years, but one pattern spans most human language: Information compression. This follows Zipf’s Law, as we tend to compress the most common words in order to convey information more efficiently. Everyday English examples of this are stop, walk, listen, eat, sleep, good and bad. 

According to the scientists behind this new body of research, the similar patterns observed in penguin speech is the first time that this has been seen outside of primates. The research team from L’Equipe de Neuro-Ethologie Sensorielle of the University of Lyon/Saint-Etienne recorded almost 600 mating calls of 28 adult African penguins between 2016 and 2017, and through careful of analysis, they found that the “words” used most often were indeed the shortest. On top of this, the longer words were made up of shorter syllables, following the Menzerath-Altmann law.

answers: Penguin speech has evolved in a similar way to human speech.
Penguin speech follows the exact same laws as human speech.

answers: Longer words are made up of more, but shorter syllables.
